tNnXlpV0t3xXpI4Xgqlw3Q.text: Aubergine and spring rolls for starters were delicious. Coconut and lychee drinks were fine but small The pho soup was ok. The service was distracted, unprofessional. Locale is crammed and loud.

3CJshDJms_aNYecBofXmmQ.text: Returned here after 3 months and noticed all the prices have gone up! Not such good value now for a large beef pho for £14. After finishing our bowls we were pretty much forced out of our tables after 1 hr to accomodate those waiting despite telling us in the beginning we had 1.5 hrs! Very disappointed with this service and not returning again if they want to operate like a Chinatown restaurant. You cannot bring a check without the customer asking for it!

NkVxdo7Tz3DYKLRso_IFPA.text: The pho here is really, really good. But it's a high-quality bowl rather than the huge bottomless soup heavens I'm used to sticking my face in. It's expensive. But it's good. The broth is flavourful and drinkable. The meat is obviously great quality, the rare steak is very tender and the other fatty cuts are a dream. But the noodles are the real star, they are hands-down the best pho noodles in London. Soft, slippery, bouncy and chewy! The holy grail of noodles and on my mind almost constantly since my last bowl. The only thing - the bowls could do with more of them! The fixings on the side were plentiful and good quality, no Thai basil though and lemon rather than lime. Also, the bird chillies come whole. I have never encountered this before! I think the idea is you put the whole chilli in the broth and get the flavour that way? But I'm a freak that likes to actually eat the chilli so I tore mine up (with my fingers - do not rub your eyes/nose/anything after doing this) and added it that way. It was spicy and awesome but maybe Cay Tre should just cut them up?We experienced none of the service problems I've seen complained about on other reviews, but it may be because Wednesday lunchtimes aren't exactly the busiest, or, possibly they've finally been open long enough to straighten everything out (it really has been ages)? The decor is pretty fancy but I liked it! My only complaint is the portion size (just not big enough) and the fact that bottled beer (Saigon, the only choice) is £4 a pop. You guys gotta know I hate my overpriced booze.It's my birthday this week and I think I'll be back to try the 'Special Pho' because nothing says "celebration" like 500 grams of meat!

aKdmLKuUIH_0f2RfQ1J-4A.text: Food was great, they mixed up my order but I guess that's expected as it was busy last Friday. I still prefer their other restaurant in Shoreditch. Small but very nice.

i8MnjmMW2oV7GC409b6Siw.text: Here we go again, to feed our pho addiction!  We came for lunch on a Sunday and it was really quite busy, with most tables full and a bustling vibe.  They have a full menu of Vietnamese food, but as always we were there for the pho.  They do have lots of pho options, beyond the standard, and I went for the flash-fried beef pho with garlic.  It came to the table quickly, with a small plate of mint, sprouts, and a hot chile.  Would've been nice if they'd sliced the chile - my fiancé did it himself and got it all over his fingers, no fun when you accidentally rub your eyes later!  Also, I would've liked coriander and basil in addition to the mint, but whatever.  Anyway, the broth was absolutely fantastic.  The best I've had yet, I think.  Even better than the broth at Pho, which is our favorite.  Blasphemy!  The noodles were a little clumpy, and the whole raw garlic cloves in the dish were too strong for me to eat, but clearly they worked wonders on the broth.  Tasty pieces of beef as well, could've been slightly more tender but they weren't too chewy either.  It was the broth that totally sold me here.  Complex, strongly flavored, comforting, amazing.  I still think pho is the best hangover cure out there!  I'd come back here for pho anytime, they know what they're doing in the kitchen!

9A-MwYCFTErxoUcwEUZNuQ.text: Vietnamese Cuisine has a secure place in my top 5 cuisines in the world and I am a regular visitor of Little Vietnam in and around Kingsland Road. Cay Tre Soho is without doubt an interesting addition to the Soho dining scene, where Vietnamese restaurants are scarce. However, compared with my favourite Vietamese joints in the East End and also compared to the original Cay Tre in Old Street, I liked the food substantially less. Overall it didn't deliver the fresh flavours and herb explosion that I find in my favourite Vietnamese eateries such as Song Que or Fernandez & Leluu Supperclub. We started with the Green Mango Salad (8.5) which came with dried shrimp and knotweed. I a sucker for Vietnamese salads but this one was rather mediocre. It didn't taste as fresh, zingy and herby as better specimens of this kind. The Grilled Aubergine (6) however, despite being a particularly unattractive plate of food, was utterly delicious and for me the winner of the evening. The sweet taste of the aubergine together with the ground pork on the top worked so well with the flavour of the fish sauce. Very nice indeed and a must have if you like aubergine. For the mains we went for the very healthy sounding Mushroom Hotpot (9). The menu stated it would come topped with crispy tofu. The flaky thing on the top that you can see here was actually pure garlic and I hate garlic in large, overpowering quantities. Apart from the missing tofu and the garlic overkill, the mushrooms were plentiful and nicely cooked. The Softshell Crab Curry (8.50) sounded intriguing. It turned out to be very heavy and also surprisingly spicy for Vietnamese food. It almost resembled an Indian curry lacking the subtle flavours of Vietnamese cooking that I like so much and replacing it with a hammer of ground spices. I nevertheless quite enjoyed it and thought that the little vermicelli dumplings for dipping the sauce added a nice touch. Where Cay Tre Soho wins is with the atmosphere which is about 10 steps up from East London Vietnamese places. Rather stylish with dim lighting and friendly as well as efficient service. While I was not blown away with the new Cay Tre, I should mention that some other food bloggers whose opinion I rate highly really loved Cay Tre Soho. The London Eater recommends to try the Pho with Ox Cheeks and Greedy Diva highly enjoyed not only the Chef's Vinh Beef. Have you given it a try yet? What did you think? Here are some photos and stuff as well:hungryinlondon.com/2011/…

Ggojty3XiZDl9H159fOIEg.text: Had a late dinner at Cây Tre last night with two friends from overseas.  Came here as had really great food last time we went.  Dunno if it was because it was late (and the love for the food was lost) but we were quite disappointed.  Very overpriced for quite small portions.  The Spring Chicken Royale was dry, the anchovy chicken wing was £6.50 for only two wings.  The ox cheek, although the meat was lovely and very tender, it was really bland and missing potatoes which is in the description.   Very disappointed.

3J9YskBIwZCnxPHXipk9_w.text: As a Vietnamese-cuisine virgin and curious bypasser of the sister restaurant in Shoreditch, I was eager to try this place out. First impressions were all positive - they've done nice work with the decor and minimalistic, but surprisingly comfortable, seating. I particularly liked the half-booth tables for large groups, which suited our group of 7.I was forewarned that the menu was a bit pricey for lunch - particularly as there was no price difference between ordering certain dishes at lunch or at dinner. This was a bit disappointing as I understand the Shoreditch branch does have a lunch special. Saying that, the food was delicious, the portions were decent, and everyone was happy, even though we had some people with very particular tastes in our group. There was one comment that the pork 'tasted a bit like kebab', but I was assured this was in fact a compliment (from a kebab-lover). It had a good crowd for lunch so there was a good atmosphere but I was again a little disappointed when the staff failed to say goodbye or thank us on our way out (I thought this was me being picky as a former waitress, but another girl in our group pointed this out).I'm going to go with the 4 stars because I think they're still getting their feet (customer service wise) and if I just had more money, I'm sure I wouldn't have noticed the price!

gYiH9bfNdz97CGgENe_q9w.text: This is a great little addition to Soho's array of cuisines. The food here is very authentic, so you'll probably have to ask the waitress for some advice if you're new to Vietnamese. My advice if you're new is to stick to the curries, they're delicious. The rolls are a bit hit and miss, as are the soups, but there are so many good meat and fish dishes on the menu you won't be disappointed. I didn't try the pho this time round but it's a signature dish so will have to sample it soon.

v0ScI8WwJHsldShg0UbYjw.text: Great broth ... This place is good but not amazing was a bit under impressed.. I had the wood ear mushroom and pork Vietnamese roll which where not to my liking more slimmy rice paper roll then filling ... Soup was a bit smaller then traditional pho size soups and I ordered the spicy soup and it was not spicy at all plus I saw the workers snacking behind the counter pretty sure that's not hygienic when cooking someone else's food ... The restaurant is in a easy to find place and is nicely decorated and designed ... Well probably not be going out of my way to come back here again

WjtCBby_4kVlNyuSpYkngg.text: Had the Saigon Pho & Shrimp summer roll. Broth was bland, noodles were like jelly- it melted in your mouth & the soup wasn't even hot- it was merely lukewarm. Highly priced for quality of food. Only thing good about this place was the meat in the pho was really good. Summer rolls were not tasty at all.

yC3XV94IgJYbnK8uala7Sg.text: Here's what I said back in 09 about Cay Tre's original location on Old Street: "Best Vietnamese in London? Maybe." I reckon the same could now apply to the restaurant's new Dean Street location. A starter course of grilled calamari with okra rocked, especially the grilled bit as there was just enough char to the bacon-y chunks of squid to have me daydreaming of exotic barbeques in balmier climes. And my main course, of Lang Son spinning roast Tamworth pork belly (stuffed with sweet curry leaves from northern Vietnam's Lang Son province, roasted with lemon and honey then served with dried shrimp chilli oil) was one of the more delicious and intriguing pork dishes I've devoured in a very long time. Both starter and main were fiery yet held delicate flavours. Since my visit, I've heard from a few friends they're not that impressed. I must admit though I really enjoyed dining here and only regret was that I wasn't with a big group of foodies keen to order and share a variety of dishes (but I will be back!). If you like the Old Street Cay Tre, I can only imagine you'll approved of the new Soho version as well. And if you love Vietnamese food but for whatever reason found Old Street's ambience or menu lacking, it might be worth your while to check out this new and more centrally located Cay Tre. The design and feel of the place is a little slicker and a lot airier than the original while the menu presents a fresher, spruced up take on Vietnamese cuisine.

dcTOsAg1yWHPANBjWp4deA.text: Never been to a non-grimey vietnamese restaurant so was slightly taken aback (in a good way) at the decor at Cay Tre.I would go back to give it a second chance, visited to have a quick lunch and escape work, summer rolls were good....food-wise though i think i ordered the wrong dish...so need to go back here to re-order...would go back for dinner though...not for lunch...To finish with a sprinkling of constructive criticism: brush up on the service, staff are somewhat dopey and not very attentive

Y3zIlSM4AoyQSaZNsocQKQ.text: A disgrace to Vietnamese food. My friends I had the classic, meatball and mushroom Pho. They said the beef wasn't cooked enough and the soup was not hot enough - which it should be so that the meat sizzles when you put it in. The meatballs were not cooked enough so that my friend wouldn't even be able to eat them. They forgot to bring the basil, lemon and soy sprouts that you usually put in your Pho yourself on three out of four orders, which we kindly reminded the waiters of. There wasn't enough Pho spice in the soups so that they tasted like nothing.. There weren't enough noodles in the classic and meatball Pho. All noodles were broken into small pieces which is not the way it should be. I found a hair including the root inside my soup. Shit happens but in this case it is simply neglectful of the restaurant not to have the cooks wear nets. The good thing is that the waiter did come to my table to apologize for the hair and of course I didn't pay for it. The ceiling fan was directed at our table so that we were cold and sitting in coats. The interior is nice though.

z_m7vk1xRg2wU42iMjN97w.text: A much better venue than its Old Street sister in terms of service.  Food-wise it could be better but does hit the spot when I'm craving some Vietnamese.

0sfpftDSwonWJFd26-NRVw.text: Bun ho hue broth okay, noodles weren't Pho, more like spaghetti.I have nothing against new English-speakers but my server (doubling as hostess) didn't seem to be completely fluent so my app order was wrong.  No big deal.  But she did forget to put the order in entirely.  Until 10 minutes later she came back to ask which main I'd ordered (bun ho hue chicken? no - beef).Not sure if there's an incipient trend in Vietnamese restaurants with nouveau modern decor.  While it's clean...it sort of seems overwrought and the menu prices reflect the back-payments they're trying to make on the upgrade.  Anyway, the shiny surfaces remind me of Pho Phuong in Toronto on Dundas West (blogto.com/restaurants/p…).

Xq8oInuLyMFIE9dvaS6zQQ.text: Great Pho and summer rolls. Pho is deeply flavoured and fragrant. Meat is a little hit and miss, some of it is quite gristly. Stock is good. Herbs provided are generous and make the soup even more deeply flavoured. Service is fine. prices are good, especially at lunch time when you can get Pho and summer rolls for a tenner. I would highly recommend it as the best Pho without having to travel to the East End. Of course, the Kingland Road has much better Pho, but this is very convenient.

iAXJxUnGLXgkA83gXw_43w.text: We ate here on a Sunday afternoon, around 4pm, and the place was deserted and yet the service was still way short of the mark. To be fair, it could just be the one member of staff that had just lost the will to live and was more interested in his final cigarette out front than bringing our food which was waiting in the dumb waiter. My girlfriends main wasn't brought until 20 mins after mine by which time I'd finished. People rave about this place, but to me, this place is teutonic, uncomfortable and overpriced for what you get. We live in a city rich in culture. There are many Vietnamese restaurants out there. Try one of the many authentic restaurants before falling for the pretty menus out front and thinking the nouveau cuisine twist will give their fare a refreshing twist; It doesn't.

OEKIxEhC4o1qy7ZkgVhZDQ.text: Hmm not sure about this one. We did go when they had only just opened (literally their first night) and the service was slooow and a bit chaotic (but sweet they kindly packed out leftovers for us). The tables are very close together, get used to practically taking part in your neighbours conversation and knocking things over when you squeeze out.The food itself was good but not spectactular, I had the piggy aubergine to start (fine) My friend had the pork ribs which came cold and almost like they'd been battered. It just wasn't what I was expecting, somthing sticky, charred and unctuos. In fact lukewarm food was a theme of the evening, not sure if that's how it's supposed to be served. My soft shell crab curry came with one teeny tiny crab floating in nice curry sauce and my friends shaking beef was just (admitedly soft and tender) very plain beef that didn't taste like it had been marinated in anything and the dipping sauce on the side tasted like pure soy sauce. It just didn't have the punch and flavour I was expecting from my travels in vietnam, maybe we ordered the wrong things but still.

XjgFaa8-r1eZBXYkmRX-1w.text: If this was in LA I'd give it 3 stars tops.  For being in London, I lowered my expectations and rated it accordingly.  This place is clean and very good for London.  I had the combination Pho w/beef, tripe, tendon, flank, and meatballs.  Meatballs sucked.  If I go back, I'd probably just stick with the beef.  Noodles are a little over, not much bite to them.  The broth is not as rich as what you'd normally expect.  I don't think it has MSG which is why it don't taste the same, but at least that means it's a cleaner broth.  Still decent though.  Would go back again.

cegUlLl5sczrzojVkdpCNA.text: One of my vietanmese friends introduced this place to me and he told me this is the best place for Vietnamese food in London he have ever found.Both the fried spring rolls and the summer rolls are amazing. The pho is really good as well including the stir fried one. I also really love their mango lassi.Because the restaurant is located in the centre of Soho, it is better to make a reservation online before the visit especailly on weekends or friday night.

qedOah1xcsMjOEkhAQe1OQ.text: This restaurant has a lot going for it, and a lot of work to do to really stand out--especially at the price points it's charging. If I had to sum it up in one word? Inconsistent.Let's break it down.Shrimp/sweet potato fritter: Quite tasty, actually, but it came as a daunting, large briquette cut into four large pieces, with a tiny bowl of nuoc cham to go with it. Something like this should really be either bite-sized or thin enough to easily make bite-sized with chopsticks; this sucker would have needed a knife and fork to be eaten with any degree of civility. Wrapped in lettuce and mint and dipped in nuoc cham, it was definitely pleasant, but could have been heavier on the shrimp and lighter on the batter that held it together.Steamed rice pancakes with pork: Good, homey, and pleasantly bland; this dish is meant to be all about the texture, with a little shot of filling, and that's what you get. The small portion was certainly a good value.Spring bowl with crab: I wish I'd had what my partner ordered! The crab 'spring rolls' were delightful, moist, and well-balanced, with a good amount of crab meat. The vermicelli bowl itself is big, but putting nuoc cham on it already is a little weird--why would you put it in the bottom of the bowl for me? And seeing as she kept stealing bits of my mint leaves, her bowl lacked on the herb department.Vermicelli with hanger steak: Disappointing. The steak was utterly flavourless. I was hoping for a hint of char-grilled flavour, some lemongrass and ginger, garlic, anything... nope. Bland, somewhat paltry portion of unseasoned steak, 'helpfully' tossed with a tremendous amount of red Thai chillies. Were those supposed to make up for the lack of flavour in the beef? The noodles, veggies, and herbs were all in their rightful proportions (could have actually been heavier on the bean sprouts and herbs), but the bland meat, lack of spring roll slices for texture, and (again) the weird thing about nuoc cham at the bottom of the bowl made this a flop, especially for the price.Vietnamese coffee with macarons: Overpriced, and the coffee didn't taste particularly fresh.We dropped a fifty on what would have been, back at my favourite Viet haunt in Philly, a $25 lunch. Yes, London; yes, Soho. I get it. But seriously, if you're going to be charging that much money for what is simple, inexpensive-to-make food, the quality has to be there, and the flavour profiles have to be authentic. Cay Tre has some good foundations in place; now it just needs to find some heart and make a serious go of it.

bhBqLpz5yL0uuxOd-aMxfw.text: I'm still sticking on 3 stars overall.  My latest trip here as part of the UYE (thanks Yee Gan!) brought me the best bowl of pho I've had in London, hands down.  However, this was also an evening trip.  Now, I'm no stranger to loud noises.  I used to do rifle shooting.  I go to a lot of extremely loud gigs (2 hours of Melvins' two drummers will deafen you for about a week).  Yet I found the volume in Cay Tre really, really uncomfortable.  The acoustics in that place can only be described as "bathroom"; I struggle enough as it is to pick conversations out of the background and at times I kind of had to give up talking and bury my face in my soup.  I mean, how else d'you think I managed to finish a good 5 minutes before everyone else?The pho is great.  I went for the super bumper combo deluxe complete with about 5 different parts of cow (I love my tendon) packed into an oversized bowl brimming with a deep brown soup topped with a glistening sheen.  I mean, I could right haikus about this.Deep, brown, delicious,Bold, fragrant, steam shimmering,Get in my belly.The broth is by far the best I've tried here, absolutely brimming with flavour yet still extremely fresh.  The assorted meaty chunks are great too, the tripe isn't tough, the tendon is rawr, and the muscly bits are tender and tasty (the meatballs too are perfect - great texture).  My main negatives were the slightly overdone noodles and the absence of cut chillis (mine could have done with a bit more spicy kick - the provided uncut chilli isn't quite potent enough).  The massive bowl is £14 - almost twice the price of some of the Kingsland Road joints.  Pricey, but given the sheer volume, it's great.  I mean, sure, it would cost (at most) 100,000 dong, but the quality of the soup and ingredients is undeniable.

ozQ2JdZ0oV81RpQ1w3lkOQ.text: My friend took me to Cây Tre especially to try out their Pho. When we looked at the menu there were no Pho listed. After we had our food, we found out that the waiter did not show us their Pho menu!!!!!We ordered Tiu Bowl (chicken, charsiu pork, beansprouts, peanuts, Pho Noodles, tangy sour sauce) for £10.00 and Saigon Stewed Pork Belly (caramelised coconut juice, hard boiled egg) for £10.75. Tiu Bowl tasted bland. I was expecting the extensive use of fresh herbs, spices, and aromatics. But none, which was a disappointment.As for Saigon Stewed Pork Belly, they used pork chop instead of pork belly! The pork chop was hard and dry with a part of a vertebra in the middle. I am no butcher but I do know pork cuts well. Pork belly is juicy and tender, showing layers of muscles and fat without vertebra or bones in the middle!I would not recommend Cây Tre if you are looking for an authentic Vietnamese restaurant that offers mind blowing dishes with fresh herbs, spices and aromatics. Remember, you have a choice and can always choose a better Vietnamese restaurant!

SctgxfogSeSfGz3Pw1-WhQ.text: Not authentic. Pho noodles are too wide to be pho noodles. Soup was broth with a cinnamon stick in it? Real broth is much more aromatic and flavorful. I would not go back. There's gotta be better.

_Wdouv35R9jarJhptkMPJw.text: Love this place , the pork buñ noodles are the best and its a big portion and there delicious !! Try it

photos.caption: Photo of Cay Tre - London, United Kingdom

z0rFWt8n9CSZaw0FpOzxCg.text: I was hunting for a good pho place near Soho square and went here based on Yelp reviews. I was quite pleased with the result. The restaurant itself is very nice and clean, not a traditional hole in the wall pho joint, much more upscale. (this is Soho after all)The broth was great, the meat was great, and the service was good. It was a little bit expensive (in the US you never pay more than maybe $13 for pho), but I suppose that's the norm in this part of town.All I had was the Saigon pho which I found to be fantastic. I would definitely go here again.

ZgWKt0kCCw3lfcjte4BiXw.text: Thumbs up to one of the best Pho I have tasted in London - classic rich and refreshing broth with flank steak. Totally yummilicious.....They do charge extra if you want other parts (e.g. meatball, tripe, tendon or shin).  Another one of my favorite dishes (if you are an aubergine fan like me) is the piggy grilled aubergine. Is it just me, but the word "piggy" sounds rather unrefined in a dish's name. It is basically a whole aubergine steamed in fish sauce garnished with mince pork. That was the first time I had something like that. Totally mind-blowing to dig into a softly-steamed aubergine.The chili salt and pepper squid was good - just the right amount of garnishing and mixed pepper batter. A bit pricey, but would be a luxurious once-a-month treat.I have also tasted their cha la lot (betel leaf wrapped pork dumplings with mashed peanuts). To be honest, I wasn't too impress. The flavor was there, but probably doesn't sit well with my liking.I am a regular patron (1-2 a month), and they fare very well in terms of consistency of their food.

IcnW9ask8d4qQ_vsfHUFWg.text: When Kingsland Road in East London just seems too far to trek to, Cay Tre in Soho is a top notch alternative for delicious Vietnamese food in London. I've had the pho and the bun cha here and both dishes live up to what they should be. More recently, I've had the bun cha - the meat is flavourful, the spring rolls are crispy and the overall dish is deliciously satisfying. Be careful on weekend nights when the restaurant can be extremely loud so could make conversation a bit difficult. But I've also been here during lunch on the weekends and during the week for dinner and it's a much more pleasant experience.

Sn2dnHxDYaw5vFauNWXxUg.text: This place has a fantastic variety of pho and other Vietnamese delights! Very very tasty. The reason for 3 stars is the service- slow, not friendly. But if you can get over that- try it! Tasty

DVnymTjy_sjh0bFZelWR0Q.text: Vietnamese. In Soho! What's not to like? Well... Though a good effort I think I will still be going to Kingsland Road when I crave Vietnamese. That said, Cay Tre is not bad, it's just that I expected more. The BBQ pork with rice vermicelli was the highlight for me. It's a dish I really enjoy which probably brought the score up a bit for me. It is very nice but it lacked the strong BBQ flavour I'm used to when ordering this dish. Apart from that it was well made. I definitely recommend this. The cat fish with caramelised fish sauce was OK, nothing spectacular. The fish flavour was very strong and sometimes almost overpowered any other flavour. Com Saigon (grilled pork chop with a fried duck egg) was nicely cooked with an interesting flavour but was quite dry and slightly bland. Trying to even out all the meat with a vegetable dish wasn't the best idea. The string beans were merely beans with garlic at a price far above what it was worth. Overall, a good place to visit if nearby but otherwise I'd stick with Kingsland Road.

x8Uk73B_ZXhdhtJArH8-rA.text: Excellent choice among the many restaurants that crowd Eastern Soho.One dish to try: Table Griddle Beef! You grill it table side and steam your own rice paper wraps.  Damn!!Try sister Viet Grill if in East End!

vBLcqiZwPDBFqIN3nm6VAQ.text: Overpriced. Over-hyped. Not fresh. LEMON with my pho? What the.. pho? Vegetarian spring rolls that have a seriously dodgy sour taste... This is the 3rd time in a row that I left unhappy both in terms of price (11 pounds for a basic pho... I know this isn't California, but that doesn't mean you have to take the piss totally) but mainly I left unhappy because of the qulity of the pho. Staff was nice, I have to say.

-f_JpCJTEZ-ayT0yukNoqQ.text: I woke up on Saturday  "morning" (read: 1 PM), after a long night out, with a craving that only a fresh bowl of noodles, broth, and beef could satisfy ... but Kingsland Rd, and it's plethora of Vietnamese options, seemed oh-so-far away from where I was in West London.Enter the Soho location of Cây Tre. The decor inside of this location is decidedly more upscale than its Old St counterpart, but the food is just as delicious. I ordered the plain beef pho, which came with fresh pho noodles (better than any of the other options I've had in London) with an incredibly delicious broth and tender beef. The crab summer rolls, filled with mint and lime, were delicious as well. The restaurant also seems to offer affordable and exciting meal deals.Just talking about it makes me want to go back again, and the lucky thing is that this branch isn't located across town!

8A4yn84Qcy7k0qBDOp9SNg.text: I like this place. Since travelling to Asia last year I have become obsessed with Asian eateries. I had the mackerel here and it was presented with the head and everything! Pretty intense! But it was so damn tasty! I also had the water spinach and don't be fooled by the boring name...so tasty! I'll definitely be back to try other things!

ciT7m7tGIc7hIhc17Hr6gQ.text: Absolutely love this place. The food is authentic and delicious, so fresh and delivered with a smile. The drinks menu is also great - awesome cocktails and an unexpectedly diverse wine list. Go for the BBQ Pork Bun noodles and the flambé banana with coconut ice cream... Yum! For evening or weekend dining definitely book ahead.

WzBnrx6rJLpB40bpPwt1Nw.text: Dont visit this restaurant, simply replicate the experience by eating a pot noodle on the northern line during rush hour.

io8msjouZbgEz5VfHGtetw.text: I think this place has a little bit of westernized flavors for Vietnamese food. I was craving Pho and decided to give it a try.  It will do in a pinch, but I didn't feel as though the flavors were as strong or clean as I've had elsewhere.

UT3gH40W6I__kL7ZZ5fCJA.text: Stick to the Old Street branch. It's like these two restaurants are completely different companies.The first visit wasn't a great experience, service wise, although the food quality was ok.The second visit I sit and wait for over 10 mins while staff stand around doing nothing, about 5 tables were in, with about the same number of staff.Also, it seems as a solo diner you are relegated to the worst seating in the house, bar stools or aisle seats that are about as relaxing as sitting on the underground!Old Street is awesome, no complaints. Dean Street, I voted with my feet after the 10 minute wait and don't plan to return.With all the competition in the area why bother.

xUt3IrCCtafnMUE3E9Mifg.text: Cay Tre Soho is different to the other branch. Very different. I mean, the food is reassuringly as good as in Hoxton but everything feels alien and a completely different experience. What you have here is a cool restaurant with staff that are much more attentive.Starting this review with the desserts, as that's by far the most important aspect of the meal, Cay Tre offer ice creams made by local ice cream parlour Gelupo. These aren't Gelupo's normal flavours. No, these are special Cay Tre flavours like Vietnamese Coffee and Vietnamese Basil, and boy are they good.The rest of the food is also absolutely delicious and expertly cooked. They are also pretty reasonable in price, particularly when you consider this is Dean Street and they could easily get away with being a bit cheeky with the prices.Service has never been a strong point in Cay Tre. In fact I kind of enjoy their indifference sometimes. Here, however, they are definitely making a bit more effort here. They're by no means perfect but, as I said, Cay Tre has never been about service.This is definitely now a go to place for a light meal in Soho.

z51f7tfGP7M6InwJLJ15Pg.text: Decided to get some pho on a wet rainy day. Seen this place a few times so decided to try it out. Tried a few of their veggie dishesThe tofu summer roll waa good and tasted fresh. The organic crispy was also very good, just the right amount of crispness and flavourfulThe noodles though were the weakest dishes.  The pho broth was slightly bland and the rice noodles Barbeque pork vermicelli had too much mint and fried onions. And the accompanying spring rolls were too greasy. The portions are a good size though. Something that could definitely improve is the service as they forgot to bring our water and were not thw friendliest.Overall an average vietnamese restaurant with nice interiors in a good location

photos.caption: Photo of Cay Tre - London, United Kingdom. Mushroom pho
Photo of Cay Tre - London, United Kingdom. Vermicelli noodles with too much crispy onions
Photo of Cay Tre - London, United Kingdom. Tofu summer rolls

s6qTCcyDDo5SZfxip1azww.text: When a Vietnamese tells you this Pho is good, then take her word for it! I have to say the beef pho in Cay Tre Soho was the best beef pho I have tasted in London. I have tried many Vietnamese restaurant in London including the popular ones near old street station, but cat tre soho got it best. And the big pho combo was BIG, humongous in fact. It used to be 12 quids but they pushed the price up to 14 now, slightly disappointed.We tried other dishes too, like the "steam pancake?" (Bánh cuon) was also nice, my boyfriend loved the Hanoi mixed pork vermicelli (bún cha Hà Noi), so much he couldn't stop talking about it on the way home.If you're in the mood, try their Lemongrass ice tea. I know it sounds weird I thought so too. But the first time we tried it it was sooo good and refreshing, it came in a big jar you can share between 2-3 people. But the second time we came back, maybe because it was very late (10.30pm), the tea was just like normal tea...with ice. A bit of a hit and miss actually.But over all great Viet restaurant, we enjoyed the food there and it's in soho so better location (IMO) than east end as you can go somewhere else (movies, clubbing etc) within a few mins walk.

photos.caption: Photo of Cay Tre - London, United Kingdom. Steam pancake and lemongrass ice tea
Photo of Cay Tre - London, United Kingdom. Hanoi mixed pork vermicelli.

TPk5vev4wmipDMfKZp6TzA.text: I haven't been to the parent Cay Tre in east London but I was excited to see an outpost of this famous Vietnamese restaurant open on Dean Street.It's a challening location for a restaurant with several restaurants having met their demise on this location in recent years. I'm not sure why Dean Street in general does struggle to attract dining custom in comparison to neighbouring Frith Street, which thrives with Arbutus, Koya and Barrafina all doing good business. However, with Ducksoup, Tonkotsu and now the trendy Burger & Lobster opening on this street, perhaps, things will start to look upThe publication of Time Out's list of the best 100 dishes in London 2012 gave me another reason to visit when it listed the beef pho at Cay Tre on that list. Like a lot of my friends in San Francisco who have been trying to eat all 100 dishes on the 7x7 best 100 dishes in San Francisco, I may now have another excuse to eat out more!Yelp buddy Kevin L joined me to experience the pho at Cay Tre. I pigged out with the large combination pho, which had everything from all cuts of beef to beefballs to tendon.I love noodles and the essence of noodle soups likes in the broth. On this count, Cay Tre's is the best I've experienced in the UK - deep rich notes of beef which comes from long simmering. I kept slurping away at the broth even when my noodles and beef was all goneThe beef was nice and tender. I think my favourite was the brisket and I love that you can get tendon in London. The English tend to be a little squeamish!I've since been back to eat here again. The summer roll and Chinatown pho weren't quite as good as the beef pho. However, I'm letting Cay Tre keep their 5 stars for having the best beef pho I've tasted in the UK

photos.caption: Photo of Cay Tre - London, United Kingdom. Chicken pho
Photo of Cay Tre - London, United Kingdom. Summer roll
Photo of Cay Tre - London, United Kingdom. Cool teapot

hHGClMLbmiYSWupMTvy0ug.text: Great!! The pho is great and I really recommend the beef thai salad. Amazing food for the price! Great atmosphere, quick service.

nEggWUdY2AC_wEi8baEicg.text: Nice environment, decent food, good for group gatherings. Will try again next time~

photos.caption: Photo of Cay Tre - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Cay Tre - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Cay Tre - London, United Kingdom

GSI7KWOTEgRGRm4BicxK-g.text: I ate here with my wife a month ago on recommendation by a Londoner. We are from the U.S. and we were not disappointed. The wait was 30 minutes and the place was packed with people. The waiters were efficient and helped us great. We ordered a traditional Vietnamese chicken dish. I cannot remember the name but it was great. The appetizers were delicious and the Vietnamese beer was smooth to drink.  We would come back. Thumbs up!

bY_meE4YgyvdkA9fr8Raog.text: Good range of options which appeals to tastes of both westerners and those seeking more authentic options. Banh cuon was the standout and the crispy softshell crab was very flavoursome.Friendly service though a bit inexperienced and "lost". However, their cheery attitude more than made up for it.

7nKCEF04QawDVy7nm7NRvw.text: I've been to the old street restaurant and this place feels like a completely different restaurant.  It has a really good vibe and really busy even for a Tuesday night so it's a good sign that the food should be relatively decent.I had the spicy pho which was, as expected, underwhelming.  I kind of wish I tried the regular one.But luckily my 2 guy friends ordered all sorts of other stuff - which teaches me to be a little more adventurous and try things that are completely different.Summer rolls - Pretty good - can't go too wildly different with this.Xeo pancake - Who woulda thought there was a Viet pancake!  Def give this a try but it is huge if you are planning to share it.Cay tre platter - I think we got the meat one.  There was this one pork chop that was DELICIOUS!  Mackerel - Huge!  Didn't think Mackerels can come this big.  I'm asian and can handle whole fish but I know a lot of people can't.Wokked pho with Beef Shin - The best dish of the night - It's kind of like a beef ho fun but way better.  Vietnamese fried rice - I love that there's a fried egg on top!

nmMyqsCXNuwsIf9NkE0hGw.text: That's my favourite restaurant in London!!! Love the lunch set menu with a classic pho and small dish that just cost £10! I think their pho noodles are freshly made whereas pho from other restaurant are more like just cooked from the dry noodles. I've been to so many Vietnamese restaurant in uk and this is my favourite!

uctdFaqWx8fTMyUpSn3FnQ.text: The food was great. We had a Spring Rolls,Pho and Aubergine with Tofu. The service was fairly quick too.My only issue was how loud the place was. It felt like being in a loud pub. We couldn't talk at all over the noise, or at least not without sharing the conversation with everyone around us.The prices are not very high, but not too cheap either. Dinner for 2, with one entree and soft drinks was almost £40.I wouldn't go here expecting a pleasant romantic dinner.

photos.caption: Photo of Cay Tre - London, United Kingdom. A full restaurant, bad acoustics

LFM3rexHgzSYBT-qnWILGA.text: WOW everything we ordered was absolutely delicious! Sweet potato and prawn fritters were fab, aubergine small plate was fantastic and the drinks were fun and strong! The place is small and VERY loud, we were there with a group of 8 on a sat night and it was really hard to hear one another. Definitely worth it!

DiY2maQy-BULk-yv6lnnMA.text: Came here with 2 friends on a Friday night when looking for a tasty dinner. We tried a few places before settling on Cay Tre but as you can imagine everywhere in Soho on a Friday night had at least an hour wait. We had to wait about 30 minutes for a table at Cay Tre but sipped on some interesting and quirky cocktails at the bar in the meantime. The bartenders were very friendly and put a lot of love into each drink. Once we were seated we decided to split a few appetizers and 2 entrees. We went with a traditional Pho and the Barbecue pork vermicelli bowl. For appetizers we got a few veggie dishes which I can't seem to remember. The reason that I have blurred out the other dishes is because of the incredible mind numbingly delicious Barbecue pork vermicelli bowl. It was without a doubt one of the best things I have eaten in a while and the 3 of us couldn't stop chopsticking away at the nearly empty bowl. For dessert we each had Vietnamese iced coffees which were incredibly tasty! I wish I worked nearby because that would be the perfect afternoon pick me up!

photos.caption: Photo of Cay Tre - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Cay Tre - London, United Kingdom

ZjvPtAueh5ElT13TwLrZmQ.text: Update from my last visit:  tried the spicy beef and pork pho this time.  Not really that spicy at all but the noodle soup came with what seemed like a never ending supply of thinly sliced beef and pork. Compared to the measly two slices I've normally gotten at ramen houses, this seemed like a right meat feast!!

CEbQ8JYM0CRzjuXWM-2xxQ.text: Mindfully made cocktails, including a Rose and Gin martini. Oh yes, the Pho here fed the addiction.

photos.caption: Photo of Cay Tre - London, United Kingdom. Rose and Gin martini

f0HM9J6m4R3aS38oaN0nzw.text: This place is my favourite Vietnamese restaurant in London. The flavours come the closest to what I grew up with back in Southern California. The carmelised catfish is exactly how my mom makes it at home. I've been coming to eat here nearly every week since they opened in 2011. They've gotten better!Vegetarian and vegan friendly - lots of options for you if you like tofu and mushrooms.

n0KBWuijnevsimXwDtWSjQ.text: Food was decent, atmosphere was okay but not as clean and crisp as in photos. I booked for group of 12 for my birthday and had to call many times to keep changing reservation and depositing more money to hold the table each time a new guest RSVPed. Fair enough, they want to make sure we show up, however even after re-confirming that day via phone, like my 60 pound deposit wasn't confirmation enough they did not have the table ready when I arrived on time.  Furthermore, half way through visit they took one of our tables away and squeezed us all together even though I booked and paid for 12 people and the place wasn't full yet. We basically had to flag down the waiter and beg for order to be taken as we had to make a theater show. The food came out quickly and was good but again had to beg for the bill. Overall the service was disorganized and it made my birthday more of a hassle to plan there, than the experience was pleasant being all scrunched up in tiny table. They didn't do anything like a dessert for my b-day either but maybe that's an american thing. Would perhaps try the food again but with so many competitors, not sure I'll chance the spotty service.

Imbd1qYiIkcPiQzk75UG3Q.text: We were on our way to Duck Soup but were side tracked by Cây Tre which was surprisingly packed for 3:30 on a Saturday afternoon. Our first impression on arrival was hardly positive, and in hindsight we should have trusted our instincts and walked out after having to wait over five minutes before anyone took notice of us.Finally allocated a table, we were guided to the back of the 'steaming' restaurant (more reek than aroma),and  before we've ordered I'm thinking about my next visit to the dry cleaners.Odours aside, the interior is snazzy, modern contemporary, unfortunately the food is not as impressive, nor was the service on our visit. As it transpired, the crowds were here more for the prices than the food. As soon as we've placed our order, the waiter asks if we're using a Groupon voucher. What a way to cheer you up before you start eating, he might as well have asked us if we had a 50% discount voucher or if instead we would be paying Silly Prices.. 'Silly Prices Please!'....That's not to say we didn't whip out our iPhones and see if we could bag a deal list minute on Groupon, alas the deal had expired, and the reduction was actually 60%! Oh well... we were here now, so we decided to carry on...It quickly dawns on us, perhaps due to the Groupon deal, the restaurant is understaffed and waiters overstretched. Service goes from bad to worse when our neighbours start to loudly complain how they have waited over an hour for one starter. The Manager comes over to try and calm the situation, and for the rest of our meal Mr and Mrs Complaints seem to have all the staff in the restaurant waiting on them hand and foot.On the other side a table of two get up to walk to the bar to pay (after waiting over twenty minutes for the bill). To be fair, our wait is not so bad, half an hour and our starter arrives, but they forget our drinks which really should have arrived long before. Our deep fried tempura shrimp is burnt on the edges; but worse, fried with its shell on, almost impossible to eat. We're left with napkins full of shell...smooth..When they do bring the drinks, the bottle of tap water is missing. The mains finally arrive, but they forget the rice. By the time it arrives, our food is verging on cold. Unfortunately the mains did not manage to save the day, my okra and aubergine curry was literally swimming in oil, a sludgy and unbearably spicy affair. This despite there being no spice indicator on the menu or a forewarning from the waiter.My partners Calamari dish was better, but nothing special. The house lemonade was akin to watered down squash. We ask for the bill and they make no attempt to offer us dessert or ask us how our meal was. Perhaps they are fed up of the truth. a 12.5% service charge is added to our bill, for the first time in living memory we decide not to pay this, get up and leave.

photos.caption: Photo of Cay Tre - London, United Kingdom

snT8XwrKiNEdQ5M_h83rAQ.text: Pho was pretty good. One of the better Pho places around London.If you come when it's busy, they may ask you to share a table.

V9x9MvI3zrz01VG-iTyx5w.text: Alright Cay Tre... I'll give you four stars.I teeter between three and four.  But the food was so good that I can't knock it down to three despite the following: - Weird waiter who initially seemed so frustrated with us.  Like he'd shoo us off with hand motions when we were trying to order beverages and would take one order at a time and walk off. but then it turned out he was just frustrated with the noise level in the restaurant, which brings me to my next point...- It is SO LOUD IN THERE!  SO SO LOUD!  SO SO LOUD THAT YOU HAVE TO YELL TO HEAR THE PERSON BESIDE YOU. LITERALLY THE PERSON BESIDE YOU CAN'T HEAR YOU WHEN YOU'RE TALKING LIKE THIS IN ALL CAPS BECAUSE IT IS SOOOOOOO LOUD!That being said, here are the positives, and why I'd likely be back for more of the craziness above:- The pho was amazeballs.  Like seriously some of the most delicious pho ever.  And the bites of some of the apps I tried were totally yumtastic too.- Air conditioning!  Blessed sweet, sweet air conditioning amidst this London heatwave!  Nectar of the gods!Thanks goes out to Yee Gan who organized this UYE solely because I said I wanted pho and that the ramen club should branch out.

9z2mBecNVeF3iVLLGlFJVg.text: I've been to this branch a few times in the past. On my latest visit yesterday, I ordered the Gia Lai Pho, which is served in two bowls - one with Pho noodle, sauteed ground pork, hoisin and herbs, and the other with beef ball and brisket in fragrant Pho broth. The portion size was much bigger than I expected - two huge bowls were placed in front of me, and they looked good and appetizing. Also good value for money as it costs the same as a normal bowl of pho.If you don't eat beef, like my friend who was dining with me that day, they also have chicken pho options which are just as tasty.We also shared a Xeo Pancake which came with chicken, shrimps, and kaichoy leaves to wrap. The pancake was thin and crisp, I preferred this version compared to the Korean pancake version which can sometimes be quite heavy.If you're craving for some Vietnamese, this would be a good place to look as it's also conveniently located in Soho. It can get quite busy during peak hours though, so be sure to get there early to avoid the queues.

photos.caption: Photo of Cay Tre - London, United Kingdom. Xeo Pancake
Photo of Cay Tre - London, United Kingdom. Gia Lai Pho

RRrAjAd-cdNUUgq9C-SGRQ.text: As I've said in other reviews, pho is all about the soup so here's my view on that soup:Beef base - excellent. Chicken base - have had better elsewhere but not terrible. I know there are other people out there who only consider hole-in-the-wall Vietnamese restaurant with no non-Vietnamese customers as measure of quality pho. Oh and the menu must also look like a dog chewed it out with stains all over. If a restaurant needs to fancy up certain cuisine and up the quality to charge more and have the "stuff" to support the higher price, I say all the power to them. For me, paying a bit more to eat in a clean, well-appointed space and wait staff that are friendly (and not throw food at me) is well worth it. Yes the menu is a bit over the top and the dishes are a bit more expensive. But this is soho in London!I say if you are in the neighbourhood give it a try!

QUnbdMIjPOeflJD2po2_uw.text: I was under the weather and in want of something hot and brothy, so went here for pho. I got the lunch deal, which was £10 for a starter and a pho. Was good value for money -- for instance, the summer rolls came in healthy portions. I was a bit disappointed with the pho, however. The noodles were a bit too thick to be authentic, and I felt like some was amissin the soup. Also, there was relatively small portion of noodles and more of undercooked meat. Overall, I've had better. It's an okay place if you're in the area but otherwise, try other places!

xeLhz4tLBL-wh9QeaWklYA.text: Had dinner at Cay Tre yesterday and it was one of the best meals I've had in a while!!!It also helped i was with a Vietnamese person so I got to try all the nice dishes. The Iced Coffee is amazing and the Chilli Salt & Pepper Squid the best I've ever had! We also had a classic Pho and Bun Sa. Just writing about it makes me want to go there again!! Try it!!

EB8U_z_cM0JWR6C5_UhYOg.text: Then we pooped into Vietnam. In a cool, materialistic setting we had a nice sit down where we had rice rolls. Not a fan.For me it was purely a texture issue but the sort of spongy texture really set me off. The taste with the mints was alright, but I have to be honest probably not a place I'm seeking out again.The reactions between my fellow tasters was quite divided; some loved it - others; not so much.===Disclaimer; this was a stop on a SoHo food safari-thing, so the review may seem rather slim but we only had a few items.

8CUVI3luoppiC_H6TsVHxg.text: classic pho is a must try.I think I can say the drip coffee (cold) served here is the best I have ever had.Seafood platter is also a good choice.

6bNEEcoemWAT4eVjY1SaTQ.text: I really didn't enjoy the food here. I tried traditional pho but wasn't impressed ...the broth wasn't as good as I'm used to ...and service was a bit not up to par

N8-ftnnzCJeV1sSnayl_wg.text: This visit was due to a failed attempt to have dinner at Burger & Lobster a couple of doors down.  We walked down the street and saw this as a viable alternative, and they got us in on a Sunday night without reservations or a wait.I had the £10.50 Saigon Pho (with steak, fatty flank, skirt flank for a hearty, rich taste) & £3.30 Coconut & Lychee drink.  Delicious, meaty, tasty, and filled me up.  A great option for dinner!

photos.caption: Photo of Cay Tre - London, United Kingdom. 10.50 Saigon Pho (with steak, fatty flank, skirt flank for a hearty, rich taste) & 3.30 Coconut & Lychee drink

CkK6Ii7CRJBJ1l-ImSzW1Q.text: If a restaurant makes you wait 25 mins for a table then it must be good, right? Well, yes and no. The place was heaving, but then so were several other nearby restaurants. And I think Soho is just one of those areas that is on a par with New York in its queuing for food vibes.We eventually got a decent corner table, if rather close to our fellow diners. I had crispy pork belly with plum sauce, my pal the chicken curry. I didnt care for the strong peppary coating on my pork, although I enjoyed the crunchy skin. The curry was well received. We then polished off an unctuous - read mmmm - choc fondant with coconut ice-cream. My glass of malbec went down a treat too. I'm giving this three rather than four stars due to the queue and because it wasn't particularly cheap. I would go back again though to try the pho and some tempting rice-wrapped rolls.

cpFuXK89qMJoXB1ZNzLCIQ.text: Can't really fault this place.Dropped in for lunch: a side and a main for £10 in central london = v.good.Pork dumplings are not what you might expect, these are very meaty meat logs of meat. Super tasty so a pleasant surprise. The Pho was lovely but by far not the best iv'e had but perhaps the best meat? Very tender and flavourful.The service was fast and snappy, food was great and price was right. What's to complain about?

No4BOV852QmvEC7g-QNlkw.text: After living in Vietnam for over a year I was happy to try this place out to see if it could help my yearning to go back sickness. Having lived there I can't help comparing the food to actual Vietnamese rather than western restaurants which, without wanting to sound like a know it all, haven't been up to scratch in my experience. Cay Tre is a busy spot and most groups will have to queue to get a seat. My friend and I must have got lucky as we got a seat straight away by the window (a great spot to people watch). Its loud and busy in here, so don't expect a quiet meal. The staff do there best to keep up but you can see its a bit of a struggle. That being said, they are friendly and as responsive as they can be. My suggestion would be to keep the front door area as a bar / waiting area that I have a feeling it was originally intended as. I'm glad I could sit and eat there, but those standing in a queue out the door could of been better accommodated with a cocktail at the bar and possibly a seat. Now the food. Quick disclaimer, I'm a vegetarian which most non vegetarian vietnamese restaurants will struggle to cater for taste wise (all too often have I had tasteless broth with soggy tofu). Cay Tre didn't let me down. I had spicy Bun Hue Chay, with both soft and crispy tofu. Would I of raved about it in Vietnam? Probably not, but I also wouldn't of been disappointed. My friend had Pho with chicken and enjoyed his portion too. And a note to other reviews I see below - Vietnamese cooking is very regional. To criticise a place for using mint in their Pho is just plain wrong and I saw it used in many, many regions. I imagine its hard to nail down a particular style in a Western restaurant when trying to cater for everyone.Price was good. Yes, I would of been shocked if the price had been one tenth of what it was if I were back in Vietnam, but I have to accept that I'm not anymore! But less than £30 for two with beer and service in Soho seems pretty good to me.

Qofs0Ou9jqEzvBf_t_8ZiQ.text: Great vietnamese from east landed in west - interior is contemporary, service is unprofessional but food and location are great! It has fresh rice rolls and pho noodles so nice and fresh... Indeed the best in central...  Try for lunch combo for £10... Great value once again....I normally come here for bowl if pho or quick dinner with rice rolls with chicken followed by grilled something with rice paper on the side.Must try if you do not feel like going east for real vietnamese...

Photo of Cay Tre - London, United Kingdom. Chicken wing appetiser

hFC8E1dqjXDitLp_0iaLQQ.text: We came for a quick meal before seeing "The Book of Mormons."  Service was good, food was average.  The beef that came in our noodle soup was very red and had to be sent back.

photos.caption: Photo of Cay Tre - London, United Kingdom. raw beef in noodle soup
Photo of Cay Tre - London, United Kingdom. crunchy rolls
Photo of Cay Tre - London, United Kingdom. appetizer

edWddnfwvd77elRmiJ1iIQ.text: We came here for Sunday lunch. The pork spring rolls were amazing! The Vietnamese coffee was also great. The lunch special with beef pho was very filling and delicious. I really enjoyed the broth and the meat was very tender. We had another pork appetizer that had a very bad smell to it and deterred me away a little bit and the service was horrible. Other than those two small faults, everything was great!

LJEXfHtu2FafQC98pQbaiA.text: Very disappointing. Food was bland. Ordered nem as starter. Waitress told us there were 6 per plate. Dish arrived, with 2 nem sliced in three pieces each. Expensive for what it is, especially in a neighborhood with such a varied choice. If you have the opportunity, try another place.

Ps8kT0kUrhdYb8G5nVWBwg.text: This is okay viet food ...though i don't think it's authentic... the lunch specials are very nice, definitely fills you up. I got the spring rolls and the pho, i didn't really like the meat in the pho...it was very different from what i'm used to in the USA, it was all the same type of meat. The broth was okay for being in UK, but if you go further outside of london you can def find authentic pho. Just a good, quick place to grab lunch when you're in soho. Nothing that really stands out... but i'd come again since the price is nice.

3V-dgzw_GjZMYdfP6cLMKg.text: Adequately flavoured well spiced and thoughtfully cooked Vietnamese fare in a friendly Soho Street. Pricing is surprisingly reasonable for a place that looks like it is priced above an average Vietnamese restaurant.There is a decent range in the menu so whether you're new to Vietnamese cuisine or whether you're trying out something new, there will always be something out there for you. Some of the dishes look a tad experimental, or perhaps, fusion. The set dinner is not a bad deal both in terms of the price and volume, and the variety. Waiters are friendly, but not necessarily helpful. Some of them seemed new to the place and even somewhat clueless as to what was on the menu. The Pho is delicious, I would say better than the one at 'Pho'. The meat is fresh and the broth is spicy and refreshing. The portion size is big, a big too big I would say (we all know that the broth will fill you up). The drinks menu is not bad either. Cocktails are well mixed, the list is fairly diverse and there are enough wines on the menu to keep you going.In spite of the fact that the place is always packed, there will always be room for you. This is a big positive for the Soho Cay Tre restaurant, where other Asian eateries will give you a lot longer wait time. The flip side is that the relatively large seating capacity results in a fairly noisy space and that's just the price you have to pay for the other positives.

UTTO-6E5GN44SZjxeuYUow.text: Disclaimer: I've never been to Vietnam and don't know what 'real' pho tastes like. ALL I WANT IS TASTY, SATISFYING FOOD AT A GOOD PRICE! And on my list of such places, Cay Tre is right up there. I only ever pop in for Pho and can't comment on anything else but OOOOOH THE BROTH - hearty, rich and beefy (and maybe a little sweeter than I'd like) but still so so good. Halfway through the meal you look at your bowl and notice how the soup's surface glistens, and you smile, thinking oh yessssss, fat is flavour.We decided to try the 'add-ons' this time round. The option to add Chinese 'you tiao' (fried dough) threw me off a little (that doesn't seem very 'authentic' but I wouldn't know..) And for £2 you only get two extra meatballs :( They're good - firm with little spots of melt in your mouth goodness but idk if they're worth a pound each :(((( Their tendons were a real surprise though! I'm not usually a fan - so often they're crunchy and bitty and unpleasant overall but ahhhh these had that magical QQ quality! Soft, gelatinous, not so much chewy but has good 'bite', a little tasteless, but boy has it made a tendon convert out of me!The restaurant's quite loud and service definitely could be better (it sometimes takes a while to get their attention) but the long and short of it is that I've been to Cay Tre many many times now and I'll keep coming back! I've also heard good things about the other dishes, maybe next time we'll give them a try.

AtRvWa7fGnMrTSL_DnNWZg.text: Hangover + 4-week hiatus without pho + eating here = A VERY HAPPY ME Tried the Saigon Pho because it was the closest thing to what we have in the States. The "24-hour" beef broth was flavorful and wasn't overly fatty. I liked the flat rice noodles and the medium rare beef slices were perfect after drowning them in my soup. Although the pho wasn't served in the massive bowls I was accustomed to, I was surprisingly satisfied. That didn't stop me from scavenging for the last floating bits though. For £10 a bowl, I wouldn't mind some more steak but perhaps I'm just being greedy. However, if you are a big eater, go for the £14 super bowl (ahah, American pun) and you'll have to get your stomach pumped. Otherwise, food is authentic. Service was adequate. Modern interior design. AND they have Sriracha!! All brownie points in my book.

Photo of Cay Tre - London, United Kingdom. Saigon beef pho

WN7FfyBMQ27IuwNoob0OJA.text: I came here a couple of weeks ago with 2 friends and I must say I was quite disappointed.the table was reserved for a certain time and when we got there we had to wait like 15 minutes to be seated, so we took a cocktail at the bar,the restaurant is very chaotic, with tables close to one another like in a cheap diner. However,  the bill we got was not that cheap! Also, it is not decorated in any particular way, could be anywhere and serving anything. the food was okayish, not particularly tasty. We ordered a plate that has a grill brought to the table and then you need to grill your little beef piece and roll it in this paperish pancakes...the quality of the ingredients was average and that is their signature dish.overall, I don't think it deserved the price we paid!

I59Buh8euL8hFyj0xuND9g.text: Cay Tre is a good option for Vietnamese food in London. They have a vast menu with a lot of authentic Vietnamese food. They also have fun and interesting drinks with a Vietnamese spin. I really enjoyed the Vietnamese iced coffee (comes with 3 macaroons) and pork spring rolls. For my entree, I had the bo luc lac (shaken beef) and it was really chewy but very flavorful.They can accommodate large parties with a reservation and despite having one, we still had a 10 min wait which was a shame.This is by far the best Vietnamese food I could find in London... however, it does not compare to the quality and flavor I'm accustomed to in the States where we're spoiled with amazing pho and other Vietnamese restaurants.

zq4ZZfJ-rolNi41qqzGT7Q.text: Visited Cây Tre for the first time and ordered the following:- Saigon pho with added beef meatballThe broth has all of the meaty, umami goodness you'd come to expect and was surprisingly enjoyable in the middle of a July "heatwave". I could imagine my enjoyment of this going up a notch if eating this on a bitter February evening.The meat is wonderfully tender, being easily torn with chopsticks and these work well when mixed with hoi sin and chilli sauce. The meatballs were worth adding and have a pleasant pepperiness. They do not feel too processed either which is an added bonus.One thing that disappointed a little was that there was some confusion as to whether the dish comes with additional beansprouts and herbs on the side. We were given a small plate with these but it wasn't clear if it was for one specific pho dish (we ordered different types of pho) or if it was meant to be shared (in which case there wasn't anywhere near enough). This small but important detail could have elevated the meal a level at least for me because I value the subtle savouriness and juice that beansprouts offer between heavy mouthfuls of beef fat and sauce.I would highly recommend Cây Tre for the quality of its food at its price point and for the atmosphere inside the restaurant. It has a quiet elegance and helpful staff fitting of a west end eatery.

b8Nt2YbcFKcYRO3Nje00TQ.text: Nice Vietnamese cafe in Soho. Fresh and clean food. Just popped in for a veggie pancake. Very good for £4. Will make a point to visit again in the evening for dinner.

photos.caption: Photo of Cay Tre - London, United Kingdom

M0dmqueXqzdB5jh8mlGPzg.text: We visited today at 2pm and had to wait for nearly an hour to have our lunch! Staff were to busy so we couldn't reach them, they also didn't even go to our table to take order.We had Bun cha Hanoi. It tasted good, except for the noodles (too dry, taste like the noodles taken out from the refrigerator). Reasonably priced food.

OLL6KBZenj6fFFk_axaQjA.text: Phenomenal Pho, the spring rolls we had were fresh and obviously made to order (but can't guarantee all the time). The special pho was great though, the noodles, the meat (so much meat) and all of the fresh veggies. I was trying to be careful not to splash, but in the end, the taste got the better of me and I slurped away, shirt be damned.Even better was the ability to come in as a walkin and them trying hard to find us a table.

xySKwqMP4AX9j3il6LvUKQ.text: We came to Cay Tre for a team dinner after work one day.  It was packed when we arrived (although, I suppose most restaurants in the Soho area are).  We had made prior reservations, so we were seated quickly at a large table in the back.I was visiting from Houston, where we have phenomenal Vietnamese food, so maybe this place is good for London standards?  But I thought overall the meal was fairly average.  The food wasn't bad, but it wasn't amazing either.  All of us ordered a variety of options from the menu (pho, claypot, rice bowls, etc...)  One of my coworkers and I ordered the same thing - the charcoaled pork steak.  While mine came out and was perfectly fine, hers was cold and she had to send it back to the kitchen.  It took them another 20 minutes to send out a replacement, at which point most of us had already finished our meals.Service was on the slow side.  I hate leaving negative reviews - again, I'll reiterate I thought the food was alright (with the exception of my coworker's cold pork steak), even though it wasn't great.OVERALL: 3/5.  There are much better options in the Soho area.  Since I'm not from the UK, I don't know if there are better Vietnamese restaurants nearby - if you're really, REALLY craving Vietnamese food, then maybe Cay Tre will do in a pinch.

photos.caption: Photo of Cay Tre - London, United Kingdom. Charcoaled pork steak with pickled daikon, steamed rice, and fried egg (not pictured).

RAdnWPYPlvK0_rIARIgAng.text: I was in London for business and ate here twice. It's definitely comfort food and delicious! A lot of places like to go crazy on salt and likes to use MSG but not this place. Not only is the food great but so is the staff, super friendly. They are busy every night so make sure to make reservations. If not, you might get lucky to sit at the community table, which is still good. I love the tofu soup, clay pot fish, Choi sum stirfy, vegetarian vermicelli bowl, and eggplant with tofu. I will definitely come back on my next trip.

Q08MoJsxWmKGkO6gfcUAhA.text: Bigger portion than most pho places I've been! Usually I'm not full after a bowl of pho but this one did it for me. I got the Saigon pho and it had huge pieces of brisket which was good. Service was also very fast! Broth was good, not too oily or salty.They had lemons instead of limes which I thought was unusual/untraditional, and no cilantro. Would go again!

photos.caption: Photo of Cay Tre - London, United Kingdom. Saigon pho

rrQk0IQ3kdmUHKtxCDej8Q.text: The Cay Tre in Shoreditch is the one I remember had good traditional Vietnamese food and there are many good restaurants there. So when I came across one with the same name in Soho, and having the biggest urge to chump on a bowl of beef pho laced with serracha, I had to try. Unfortunately I was not impress. First notable thing was, they didn't soak the pho in cold water straight after cooking it, so the texture of the rice noodle, became overcooked and slightly mush. I usually also finish the broth, but it was salty. The other negs, had to keep pestering staff for some chopsticks and spoon, after they brought out the food, if this was some kind of torture, it was not funny. We came about 7pm, and half the drinks were sold out. I was really dying for sweet ice coffee, I guess its not my day. Moving on, the interior, I thought was quite nice, very slick, and very big, considering how small it looked from the outside. The final bill came, slightly more pricey, but expected as in central London. Could have been better food quality. So its an average score from me.

zb_kB1XT4ZklsjSI_ndNCQ.text: I had dinner here with my brother and cousin, and we thoroughly enjoyed it. We thought we would be adventurous and order a range of dishes from the menu to share, and everything was delicious. My favourites were the braised ox cheeks, the catfish stew, and sweet ribs. The restaurant is in a convenient location, and usually has a good crowd. We went in at around 7.30pm and the place was packed with a very good atmosphere. The pho soups also looked very good. Prices are decent as are portions. As far as Vietnamese food goes, this was authentic and very good.

photos.caption: Photo of Cay Tre - London, United Kingdom

Fzabfsto-B6kDDJhEv2PjQ.text: Absolutely love this place! Recommend getting the Ha Noi garlicky pho and stir fried water spinach!

Ozjwd_4IDDgYRtxWFHxt_Q.text: The wind was cutting on this day and I needed a soup noodle to warm me from the inside.  Pho always works wonders for this job.  The version here reminds me of the Pho in the north or the Hanoi (original) version.  I thoroughly enjoyed it and was surprised how clear but tasteful the broth was.  Even the noodles were soft and fresh.Made me wish I was back in Vietnam but this will do in London.

photos.caption: Photo of Cay Tre - London, United Kingdom. Pho Original with fresh chilis.

n0V8ivjhbCbhTvCpzqqX0w.text: Was referred by a tour guide to check out this place and it was a pretty hip and young crowd over the weekend. My Vietnamese friend was able to chat with the wait service in her native tongue and they were all very friendly people here.  The Em Yue Anh baby drink with Absolute vodka, passion fruit liquor lime and grenadine was light and refreshing and it wasn't too strong and that was perfect for me. We next enjoyed the green papaya salad but I am accustomed to shrimp and the beef served was brisket and dry and it should have been served with a beef jerky in the traditional Vietnamese way. The flavoring was good though. Next we tried the Cay Tre platter for two called the wrap & roll which was done very well. The Vietnamese style egg roll was done perfectly with rice wrapping which my friend says is much harder to do but is traditionally done this way so kudos to the chef for that. The spring roll was okay but the rice wrap was a little too firm however I really enjoyed the fresh basil and mint that stood out in the wrap. The beef roll (Bo lo lat) was tender and wonderfully seasoned. Lastly we finished off dinner with the Hanoi Garliky pho which is different from traditional pho because the beef is sautéed rather than served raw and then cooked in the broth. The beef was good but they didn't have enough mint basil complement and they gave lemon instead of lime to season the broth. The broth was also kind of bland. I didn't taste any fish sauce and it wasn't with any salt. There was a large clove of garlic in the soup but I didn't taste any garlickiness in the broth either. It wasn't bad, but it wasn't great either. All in all I would come back and try other foods on the menu mainly because the service was so nice.

photos.caption: Photo of Cay Tre - London, United Kingdom. Hanoi Garlicky Pho
Photo of Cay Tre - London, United Kingdom. Cay Tre wraps
Photo of Cay Tre - London, United Kingdom. Green papaya salad

H8bJR3dgtm6lYKOUcB6Z7Q.text: I have had Pho in just about every country we travel and my wife eats it almost every week at home. So this review is coming from a place of knowledge. That being said...This place is fantastic. (I would stop there but you know Yelp makes you write more). The frog legs were some of the best I ever had. The minced chicken dumplings (because I can't remember what they called them) were the single best thing we ate a week in London. I LOVE Hanoi style Pho and this is the only place other than North Vietnam that I have found that makes it (which is crazy if you know the difference). Grace had Saigon style, I had Hanoi style and my niece had veggie. All were amazing. Best part, 3 of us ate and drank with starters for £85.

eTrQr1IW811n-ce67j61yQ.text: I heard that the pho here is good.  Unfortunately, again like Mian Tay which they also say has one of the best pho in London, just didn't have the punch and was not flavourful enough.  I thought it was quite bland as well.  I think the Vietnamese restaurant in London is lacking a real authentic pho.  Hopefully, a new restaurant will fix this.  That said, I was here only for the pho but the menu looks like there is a real good spread of authentic Vietnamese cuisine.  I just need to come back and try them to provide a proper feedback on other dishes.  Reasonable price for a Soho restaurant.

Photo of Cay Tre - London, United Kingdom

HB-aN8jb4qR-jGb8AGz4lw.text: Fair warning: if you love this place, don't continue reading this and I feel bad that you haven't had really good authentic Vietnamese food yet, lol. Remember: ONLY eat at Vietnamese restaurants where the majority of patrons are actually Vietnamese if you want authentic and delicious food. Let's start off with the pho. They had about 15 options for different types of pho. AREYOUFCKNKIDDINGME. Anyway, I couldn't find anything redeeming about the pho even though I really wanted to! I swear! My sister wrote it off so quickly that I didn't believe her. Then I tried it. The meat was tough that night, they don't even use the right herbs (they use mint, wtf? The waitress said they don't grow basil on this side of the pond. Seriously?  Might as well give me a hotdog with tofu on it), and the broth (which is the most important part of pho) was tasteless and had no depth.We also got the Banh Cuon which is one of my favorite Vietnamese dishes. The one thing they messed up on with this dish was the sauce that goes with the banh cuon -- nuoc mam Cham. Instead of that, they gave me some type of sauce with black pepper in it. I can't eeeeeven. So by now I was crying inside about the fact that there are horrible Vietnamese restaurants out there and that I was eating at one of them. In London. On vacation. The only two redeeming things (why I'm giving it 2 stars) about this restaurant was the CHA GIO (egg rolls-you can't mess up something that's fried) and our waitress who was extremely patient with my snooty butt. I had a moment where I was sticking my nose in the air asking "where's this, where's that, why is it like that, who eats that, blah blah blah." Sorry. I was just Hangry. I'm human. Anyway, if you want real authentic Vietnamese...well, GTFO of London.
